   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical decline, now back on paralytics
   and 100% FiO2.  Oxygenation remains tenuous.  Marked hypoxemia.
   Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and possible infection
   and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear as to component of
   GVHD.  No evidence for Pneumocystis, but Bactim now resumed empirically
   after discontinuation last week.  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole/Bactrim).
   Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if
   possible, and adjust PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  Consider ECMO evaluation, but unable to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   ARDS, less likely infection (ex. VAP), but may in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue antibiotics, continue net diuresis.
   Await pending bronchoscopy results.  Need to F/U final BAL report on
   viral cytopathic effects.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing.  Consider trial of NO to determine responsiveness,
   eligibility for longer acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or
   pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Would adjust
   benzodiazepines back to doses comparable to last week.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 continue TF, but limited by proning position.
   [**Month (only) 51**] need to initiate TPN.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplant over 200 days ago. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient is mechanically ventilated and requires 100% oxygen to maintain adequate oxygenation. His respiratory failure is attributed to ARDS, possible infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. He is also experiencing pulmonary infiltrates, which are likely related to ARDS, and has a history of pleural effusions.

The patient's neurological status is sedated and paralyzed, and he is being monitored closely for signs of sepsis. He has a history of lactic acidosis, which is likely related to evolving sepsis, and is being treated with aggressive fluid resuscitation. He also has acute renal failure, which has resolved, and is being monitored closely for signs of recurrence.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of viral cytopathic effects in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen, which suggests a viral etiology for his respiratory failure. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and is being monitored closely for signs of infection.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and he may require further escalation of his ventilator settings or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Infection: The patient is at high risk for developing a nosocomial infection, particularly given his prolonged hospitalization and immunocompromised state.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue, and he may require further treatment with antibiotics and other medications to manage his symptoms.
4. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is likely to continue, and he may require further treatment with corticosteroids and other medications to manage his symptoms.
5. Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis is likely to continue, and he may require further treatment with antibiotics and other medications to manage his symptoms.
6. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, but he is at high risk for developing further kidney damage due to his underlying disease and treatment.
7. Hepatitis B: The patient is being treated with lamivudine for his hepatitis B, but he is at high risk for developing further liver damage due to his underlying disease and treatment.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to continue, and he may require further treatment with blood transfusions and other medications to manage his symptoms.
9. Nutritional support: The patient is at high risk for malnutrition due to his underlying disease and treatment, and he may require further nutritional support to manage his symptoms.
10. ICU-acquired weakness: The patient is at high risk for developing ICU-acquired weakness due to his prolonged hospitalization and sedation.

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS:  The patient shows with improved
   oxygenation while in prone position, but continues to shows overall
   worsening of oxygenation, and is not able to tolerate being in supine
   position for extended periods of time.  APRV ventilation did not result
   in significant improvement in oxygenation this AM.
   - Continue Prone ventilation and adjust vent settings and positions as
   needed with goal PO2>60,  will tolerate pCO2 in 80s.
   - continue to wean FIO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - Continue on Propofol, Valium, Methadose and Versed for sedation/pain
   control
   - decrease Midazolam to 10 as tolerated
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium for now
   - F/u with Micro report of CMV findings on prior BAL.
   - Discussion of prognosis and goals of care with the family
   -Hold PO meds and tube feed including Lamivudine for now given pt. in
   prone position, but will need to consider other med options and TPN
   feeds (IV access may be a problem) if in prone position for extended
   period of time
   # Sepsis:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential given
   immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for
   PMN
s or organisms. BAL: report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL,
   to be discussed with Micro.  C diff [**11-17**] negative.  B-glucan and
   galactomannan negative x 2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  Lactate
   decreased to 2.6 from 2.9 today.  Pt. started on Linezolid due to
   concern for VRE.
   - f/u ID recs
   - continue Meropenem, Voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**]) - increasing
   LFT's may necessitate changing dosing or d/c'ing medication and
   switching to a different [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - continue Linezolid to cover for VRE
   - f/u pending blood cultures
   - Increase Solumedrol dose to 40mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - Increase Acyclovir to q8hrs frequency
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   # ARF:
   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   -continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission, but
   probably approaching diuresis limits given current CVP 4 and elevated
   bicarb
   - continue lasix drip with goal of even today
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp. DDX includes GVHD vs. meds vs.
   infection
   - LFTs continuing to trend down today  - will continue to monitor given
   Voriconazole use in this patient.  Will re-assess Voriconazole use if
   LFTs continue to climb
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - Continue decreased solumedrol dose per heme/onc recs
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   # Hep B:
   - Hold lamivudine for now given in prone position
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Hold tube feeds today as the pt. in prone position.  Will plan to
   restart TPN if the pt. remains in prone position for extended periods
   of time.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with ALL who underwent single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the ICU due to CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and prone positioning to improve oxygenation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 61 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/62 mmHg. She has a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 100%. Her laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.1 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.1 g/dL, and platelet count of 289 K/uL.

The patient is receiving various medications, including propofol, valium, methadone, and versed for sedation and pain control, as well as cisatracurium for paralysis. She is also receiving antibiotics, including meropenem, voriconazole, and linezolid, and has a prophylactic regimen for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and she requires continued mechanical ventilation and prone positioning to improve oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and her current laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.1 K/uL, which may indicate ongoing infection.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 7.1 g/dL, which may indicate ongoing bleeding or inadequate erythropoiesis.
4. ARF: The patient's creatinine level has declined to 0.8, which may indicate improved renal function, but she remains at risk for acute kidney injury due to her underlying medical condition and medications.
5. Volume overload: The patient has a significant volume overload, which may be exacerbated by her prone positioning and mechanical ventilation.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, which may indicate ongoing liver damage or toxicity from medications.
7. GVHD: The patient has a history of GVHD, which may be exacerbated by her immunosuppressive medications and underlying medical condition.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of infection, and her current laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.1 K/uL, which may indicate ongoing infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her mechanical ventilation settings and prone positioning as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids, and monitor her response to treatment.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's ARF and adjust her medications and fluids as needed to prevent further kidney damage.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's volume overload and consider diuretics or other treatments if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's elevated LFTs and consider adjusting her medications or dosing if necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's GVHD and consider adjusting her immunosuppressive medications if necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust her antibiotic therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone chemotherapy and single cord blood transplantation. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

The patient has been diagnosed with CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She is being treated with various medications, including gancyclovir, voriconazole, linezolid, and meropenem.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 61 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/62 mmHg. Her respiratory status is improving, with a PaO2 of 144 mmHg on 70% FiO2. She is still intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient has a number of medical complications, including:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient is still experiencing respiratory failure and is being treated with prone ventilation and NO.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a wide differential diagnosis for her sepsis, including multifocal pneumonia, and is being treated with antibiotics.
3. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, and she is being monitored for recurrence of GI bleeding.
4. ARF: The patient's Cr has declined to 0.8, and she is being monitored for signs of kidney injury.
5. Volume overload: The patient is experiencing significant volume overload, and her CVP is elevated.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's LFTs are elevated, and the etiology is unclear. She is being monitored for signs of liver injury.
7. ALL: The patient is on chronic immunosuppression, and her BMT team has recommended continuing her current medications.
8. Hep B: The patient is being monitored for signs of hepatitis B.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Prone ventilation and adjustment of vent settings as needed.
2. Weaning of FiO2 as tolerated.
3. Change of NO from 10 ppm to 5 ppm if tolerated, and consideration of switching off NO.
4. Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium.
5. Continue sedation with Propofol, Methadone, and Versed.
6. Hold PO meds and tube feed for now, but consider restarting TPN if the patient remains in prone position for extended periods.
7. Monitor Hct and transfuse PRBC as needed.
8. Continue lasix drip with goal of diuresis today.
9. Monitor LFTs and re-assess Voriconazole use if LFTs continue to climb.
10. Continue chronic immunosuppression and BMT team recommendations.

The patient's code status is DNR (no chest compressions or shocks), and her disposition is [**Hospital Unit Name 1**].

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  No evidence for Pneumocystis, but Bactim now
   resumed empirically after discontinuation last week.  Continue with
   broad spectrum empirical antibiotics
   (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole/Bactrim).  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  Continue NO, with hope to be able to wean to d/c if
   able to maintain adequate SaO2 and pO2.  Considered ECMO evaluation,
   but unable to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   ARDS, less likely infection (ex. VAP), but may in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue antibiotics (including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.  Await pending
   bronchoscopy results.  Final BAL report demonstrated viral cytopathic
   effects --> currently on Gancyclovir.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so eligible for longer acting
   [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Would adjust
   benzodiazepines back to doses comparable to last week.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 continue TF, but limited by proning position.
   [**Month (only) 51**] need to initiate TPN.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient is sedated and paralyzed, and has been receiving inhaled nitric oxide (NO) to improve oxygenation and reduce pulmonary hypertension.

The patient's respiratory status has improved with the initiation of NO, but he remains on mechanical ventilation. He has a history of ARDS, possible infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The patient's pulmonary infiltrates are likely due to ARDS, and he is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient has also developed lactic acidosis, metabolic alkalosis, and acute renal failure, which have been attributed to sepsis and ATN. His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, possibly due to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

The patient's nutritional support is limited by his proning position, and he requires total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He is also at risk for dehydration due to his positive fluid balance.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia due to his intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and his current condition may be exacerbated by his positive fluid balance and elevated LFTs.
3. GVHD: The patient's elevated LFTs may be due to GVHD, and he requires ongoing monitoring and treatment.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation and NO therapy.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if he continues to have positive fluid balance and elevated LFTs.
6. Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis may worsen if he continues to have sepsis and ATN.
7. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis may worsen if he continues to have contraction alkalosis due to his active diuresis.
8. Dehydration: The patient is at risk for dehydration due to his positive fluid balance, and he requires ongoing monitoring and treatment.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's limited nutritional support may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not addressed.
10. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiogenic pulmonary edema and pulmonary hypertension may worsen if not treated promptly.

   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive

   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to
   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  Continue NO, with hope to be able to wean to d/c if able to
   maintain adequate SaO2 and pO2.  Considered ECMO evaluation, but unable
   to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to

   positive fluid balance.  Continue with broad spectrum empirical
   antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.  Await pending
   bronchoscopy results.  Final BAL report demonstrated viral cytopathic

   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so eligible for longer acting

  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He has responded well to inhaled nitric oxide (NO) and is currently on a high FiO2. The patient is also receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, diuretics, and steroids for possible infection and GVHD.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with severe hypoxemia and evidence of right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo. His neurological status is sedated and paralyzed, and he has mild lactic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis. He has also had acute renal failure, which has resolved, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs), which are currently stable.

The patient's fluid balance is positive, and he is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to limited enteral nutrition. His anemia is normocytic, and he is transfused for a hemoglobin level < 21.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia due to his immunocompromised state and prolonged intubation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and his current positive fluid balance and elevated LFTs suggest ongoing infection.
3. GVHD: The patient's GVHD is ongoing, and his elevated LFTs and anemia may be related to this condition.
4. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is severe, and he may be at risk for further respiratory deterioration.
5. Right-to-left shunt: The patient's right-to-left shunt may worsen his hypoxemia and increase his risk of cardiac complications.
6. Lactic acidosis: The patient's mild lactic acidosis may worsen if his sepsis is not adequately managed.
7. Acute kidney injury: The patient's previous acute kidney injury may recur if his fluid balance is not managed appropriately.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's limited enteral nutrition and ongoing positive fluid balance may lead to malnutrition and further compromise his immune function.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, including his oxygenation and ventilation requirements.
2. Maintain a high index of suspicion for pneumonia and sepsis, and treat promptly if suspected.
3. Manage the patient's GVHD aggressively, including adjusting his medications and monitoring his LFTs and anemia.
4. Continue to provide total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to support the patient's nutritional needs.
5. Monitor the patient's fluid balance closely and aim for a negative balance to reduce his risk of further complications.
6. Consider early tracheostomy to facilitate weaning from mechanical ventilation and improve the patient's overall respiratory status.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status, including his right-to-left shunt, and adjust his management accordingly.

   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: Ms. [**Known lastname **] displayed improved
   oxygenation while in prone position with NO.  There is significant
   improvement in the appearance of lungs on CXR over the past several
   days.   However, she displays significant facial swelling and skin
   breakdown, so she will not be able to tolarate being in RotaProne bed.
   - Switch to  Triadyne II bed from RotaProne
   - Switch to Pressure Control ventilation with the goal tidal volume
   identical to current
   - continue to wean FIO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - Continue on Propofol, Methadone and Versed for sedation/pain control
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium. Will attempt to stop in the
   near future.
   - Re-start PO meds and tube feed including Lamivudine for now given pt.
   in prone position.
   - F/u BMT and ID recs
   # Sepsis:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Signficant radiographic
   improvement on CXR.  Wide differential given immunosuppression but
   influenza and other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL
   was negative, urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less
   than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL:
   report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL, to be discussed with
   Micro.  C diff [**11-17**] negative.  B-glucan and galactomannan negative x
   2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  .  Pt. started on Linezolid due to
   concern for VRE.
   - f/u ID recs, BMT recs
   - continue Meropenem, Voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - continue Bactrim
   - continue Linezolid to cover for VRE
   - f/u pending blood cultures
   - Continue Solumedrol at 40mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue Ggancyclovir
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   # ARF:
   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   -continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission, given
   improving bicarb, will attempt to diurese 0.5-1 L today.
   - continue lasix drip with goal of 500-1000cc negative today

   to climb

   - Re-start Lamivudine

   Re-start tube feeds today .

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is currently experiencing sepsis, pneumonia, and respiratory failure.
* She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 90% and PIP of 37 cmH2O.
* Her vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 61 bpm, blood pressure of 103/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93%.
* She has significant facial swelling and skin breakdown, including a stage II decubitus ulcer at the anus.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **ARDS/Respiratory Failure:** The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS is likely to continue, given her persistent need for high FiO2 and PIP. Close monitoring of her oxygenation and ventilation is essential to prevent further deterioration.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient's sepsis is multifactorial, with potential sources including pneumonia, bacteremia, and urinary tract infection. Close monitoring of her infection markers, such as white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, is necessary to guide antimicrobial therapy.
3. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia is likely to persist, given her ongoing blood loss and lack of erythropoietin production. Transfusion support may be necessary to maintain her hemoglobin levels.
4. **Acute Kidney Injury (ARF):** The patient's ARF is likely to continue, given her ongoing need for diuretics and fluid management. Close monitoring of her renal function and electrolytes is essential to prevent further deterioration.
5. **Volume Overload:** The patient's significant volume overload is likely to continue, given her ongoing need for diuretics and fluid management. Close monitoring of her fluid status and electrolytes is essential to prevent further deterioration.
6. **Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs):** The patient's elevated LFTs are likely to continue, given her ongoing use of medications such as Voriconazole. Close monitoring of her liver function is essential to prevent further deterioration.
7. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's gastrointestinal complications, including diarrhea and abdominal distension, are likely to continue, given her ongoing use of immunosuppressive medications and antibiotics. Close monitoring of her gastrointestinal function is essential to prevent further complications.
8. **Skin Breakdown:** The patient's skin breakdown, including the stage II decubitus ulcer at the anus, is likely to continue, given her ongoing immobility and pressure ulcer risk. Close monitoring of her skin integrity is essential to prevent further complications.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Continue antimicrobial therapy and monitor infection markers closely.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion support as necessary.
4. Continue diuretic therapy and monitor the patient's fluid status and electrolytes closely.
5. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust medication therapy as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal function and adjust medication therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's skin integrity and adjust pressure ulcer prevention measures as necessary.
8. Consider consultation with a wound care specialist to optimize pressure ulcer prevention and management.

   ventilation did not result in significant improvement in oxygenation
   this AM.
   - Continue Prone ventilation and adjust vent settings and positions as
   needed with goal PO2>60,  will tolerate pCO2 in 80s.
   - continue to wean FIO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - change NO from 10 ppm to 5ppm if patient tolerates; then consider
   switching off NO. If desaturation, can increase FiO2.

s or organisms. BAL: report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL,

   - continue Bactrim

   - f/u pending blood cultures

   - continue gancyclovir (no acyclovir)
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - transfuse 1u PRBC today
   -check post xfusion HCT
   # ARF:
   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   -continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission, but
   probably approaching diuresis limits given current CVP 4 and elevated
   bicarb
   - continue lasix drip with goal of even today
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp. DDX includes GVHD vs. meds vs.
   infection
   - LFTs continuing to trend down today  - will continue to monitor given
   Voriconazole use in this patient.  Will re-assess Voriconazole use if
   LFTs continue to climb
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - Continue decreased solumedrol dose per heme/onc recs
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   # Hep B:
   - Hold lamivudine for now given in prone position
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Hold tube feeds today as the pt. in prone position.  Will plan to
   restart TPN if the pt. remains in prone position for extended periods
   of time.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. She has a history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and has been proned to improve oxygenation.

24-hour events:

* The patient was prone and changed from 10 ppm to 5 ppm of nitric oxide (NO), which improved oxygenation.
* She desaturated to 88% on FiO2 of 70% and was transfused with 1 unit of packed red blood cells (PRBC) due to a hemoglobin (Hb) level of 21%.
* The patient was examined while turning and developed a stage II decubitus ulcer at the anus.
* She desaturated to 85% on FiO2 of 80 and was given an additional dose of propofol and methadone.

Assessment and Plan:

* The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS and is being treated with prone ventilation, FiO2, and NO.
* The plan is to continue prone ventilation, wean FiO2 as tolerated, and adjust vent settings and positions as needed.
* The patient will be continued on propofol, methadone, and versed for sedation/pain control.
* She will be transfused with PRBC as needed to maintain a Hb level of 26.2.
* The patient will be monitored for signs of sepsis, anemia, acute kidney injury (ARF), and volume overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Sepsis: The patient has a history of multifocal pneumonia and is at risk for sepsis. The plan is to continue monitoring for signs of sepsis and to adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
* ARDS: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS and is at risk for further deterioration. The plan is to continue prone ventilation and adjust vent settings and positions as needed.
* Anemia: The patient has a low Hb level and is at risk for further anemia. The plan is to continue transfusing PRBC as needed and to monitor Hb levels.
* ARF: The patient has a history of ARF and is at risk for further kidney injury. The plan is to continue monitoring Cr levels and to adjust medication dosing as needed.
* Volume overload: The patient has significant volume overload and is at risk for further fluid accumulation. The plan is to continue monitoring CVP and to adjust fluid management as needed.
* Elevated LFTs: The patient has elevated LFTs and is at risk for further liver injury. The plan is to continue monitoring LFTs and to adjust medication dosing as needed.
* CMV viremia: The patient has a history of CMV viremia and is at risk for further CMV disease. The plan is to continue monitoring for signs of CMV disease and to adjust antiviral therapy as needed.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple medical complications and will require close monitoring and management in the ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to
   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  Continue NO, with hope to be able to wean to d/c if able to
   maintain adequate SaO2 and pO2.  Considered ECMO evaluation, but unable
   to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue with broad spectrum empirical
   antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to

   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor

   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.

 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.

 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's respiratory status has improved with the initiation of inhaled/exogenous nitric oxide (NO), which has helped to improve oxygenation and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction. He remains on paralytics and is being closely monitored for signs of improvement.

The patient's pulmonary infiltrates have improved radiographically, and he is being treated with broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics. His hypoxemia is thought to be contributing to his severe respiratory failure, and he is being considered for longer-acting NO therapy.

The patient's neurological status is sedated and paralyzed, and he is being maintained on benzodiazepines and narcotics. His lactic acidosis is thought to be related to evolving sepsis, and he is being closely monitored.

The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, and he is being monitored for any signs of recurrence. His elevated liver function tests (LFTs) are thought to be related to possible graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), and he is being closely monitored.

The patient's fluid status is net positive, and he is being managed with a goal of achieving a net negative daily fluid balance. His sepsis has resolved, but he remains at risk for recurrent sepsis.

The patient's overall clinical status is critical, and he is being managed in the intensive care unit (ICU) with close monitoring and treatment of his various organ dysfunctions.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Progressive respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to increased hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for recurrent sepsis, which can lead to multiorgan dysfunction and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's renal function can deteriorate further, leading to increased risk of acute kidney injury and end-stage renal disease.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function can deteriorate further, leading to increased risk of liver failure and death.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status can deteriorate further, leading to increased risk of cardiac arrest and death.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status can deteriorate further, leading to increased risk of neurological deficits and death.
7. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient is at risk for hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract or lungs, which can lead to increased risk of death.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment of his various organ dysfunctions to prevent these potential complications and improve his clinical status.

 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent

 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved

   positive fluid balance.  Continue with broad spectrum empirical
   antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.

 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.6°F)
* Heart rate: 64 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 124/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* SpO2: 95%

The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a FiO2 of 90%. He is also receiving propofol and cisatracurium infusions for sedation and paralysis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 10.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 290 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.8 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 456 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) shows diffuse pulmonary infiltrates, which are attributed to ARDS. He also has a pleural effusion, which is improving.

The patient has a number of medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and immunosuppressants, as well as medications to manage his respiratory and cardiovascular status.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust FiO2 and inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.
* Monitor pleural pressures and CXR.
* Prepare to move to a tracheostomy tube if the patient improves to allow the procedure to be performed safely.
* If the patient develops profound hypoxemia, resume NO and consider ECMO evaluation (but unable to transfer safely).
* Continue broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics, including Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis.
* Continue net diuresis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia
* Sepsis

   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

   oxygenation while in prone position with NO.  There is significant
   improvement in the appearance of lungs on CXR over the past several
   days.   However, she displays significant facial swelling and skin
   breakdown, so she will not be able to tolarate being in RotaProne bed.
   - Switch to  Triadyne II bed from RotaProne
   - Switch to Pressure Control ventilation with the goal tidal volume
   identical to current

   - Continue on Propofol, Methadone and Versed for sedation/pain control
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium. Will attempt to stop in the
   near future.
   - Re-start PO meds and tube feed including Lamivudine for now given pt.
   in prone position.
   - F/u BMT and ID recs

   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Signficant radiographic
   improvement on CXR.  Wide differential given immunosuppression but
   influenza and other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL
   was negative, urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less
   than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL:

   - renally dose meds

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent single cord blood transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presented with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and vasopressors. She was initially treated with RotaProne bed and APRV ventilation, but switched to Triadyne II bed and PCV ventilation due to facial swelling and skin breakdown.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, with significant improvement in oxygenation and lung appearance on CXR.
* Cardiovascular: Maintaining blood pressure off pressors.
* Hematological: Anemia, with stable Hct and no recurrence of GI bleeding.
* Renal: ARF, with Cr declining to 0.8, close to baseline.
* Fluid balance: Volume overload, with significant volume overload since admission.
* Hepatic: Elevated LFTs, with etiology unclear.
* Infectious: Sepsis, with multifocal PNA on CT chest, and negative results for influenza and other respiratory virus panel, AFB smear on BAL, and urine legionella.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, requiring more aggressive ventilation and oxygenation support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen, leading to organ failure and increased mortality.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to increased risk of bleeding and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
4. ARF: The patient's ARF can worsen, leading to increased risk of kidney failure and mortality.
5. Volume overload: The patient's volume overload can worsen, leading to increased risk of cardiac failure and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Hepatic failure: The patient's elevated LFTs can worsen, leading to liver failure and increased risk of mortality.
7. Infectious complications: The patient's sepsis can lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation and oxygenation support as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and vasopressors, and consider additional antibiotics if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's ARF with diuretics and consider renal replacement therapy if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's volume overload with diuretics and consider vasopressors if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's hepatic function and consider adjusting Voriconazole use if LFTs continue to climb.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infectious status and consider additional antibiotics or antivirals if necessary.

   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

   oxygenation while in prone position with NO.  There is significant
   improvement in the appearance of lungs on CXR over the past several
   days.   Currently on APRV with FIO2 100%.
   - wean FiO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - Continue on propofol, methadone, midazolam for sedation/pain control
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium. Will reconsider weaning
   cisatracurium daily.
   - F/u BMT and ID recs
   # Sepsis:
   Afebrile. Maintaining BP off pressors. Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Signficant radiographic
   improvement on CXR.  Wide differential given immunosuppression but
   influenza and other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL
   was negative, urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less
   than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL:
   report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL, to be discussed with
   Micro.  C diff [**11-17**] negative.  B-glucan and galactomannan negative x
   2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  .Pt. started on Linezolid due to
   concern for VRE.  BAL from [**11-10**] showed CMV-like cytopathic effect, and
   CMV viral load from [**2114-11-27**] showed 1160 copies/mL.

   - continue Voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - continue Bactrim

   - Continue Solumedrol at 40mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - increase gancyclovir  to 240 mg (5 mg/kg) [**Hospital1 7**]
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   # ARF:
   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission,
   although this has improved significantly in past few days
   - continue lasix drip with goal of 1.5 L negative today
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp. DDX includes GVHD vs. meds vs.
   infection
   - LFTs improved today  - will continue to monitor
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   # Hep B:
   - Continue Lamivudine

   Nutrition:
   Re-start tube feeds today.  Will start TPN as well once access is

   Lines:

   Arterial Line - [**2114-11-10**] 02:00 AM

   DVT: heparin, venodynes
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:  bundle
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR (no chest compressions or shocks)

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following are the key points and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Key Points:**

1. The patient is a 52-year-old female with ALL who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis.
2. She is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated with APRV mode and FiO2 of 100%.
3. Her oxygenation has improved significantly, and she is currently saturating in the low 90s.
4. She has a history of anemia, ARF, volume overload, and elevated LFTs, which are being managed accordingly.
5. She is on multiple medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and immunosuppressants.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP):** Given the prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of VAP, which can lead to further respiratory failure and increased mortality.
2. **Septic shock:** The patient's sepsis is not fully controlled, and there is a risk of septic shock, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death.
3. **Acute kidney injury (AKI):** The patient's ARF is not fully resolved, and there is a risk of AKI progression, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and increased mortality.
4. **Gastrointestinal bleeding:** The patient has a history of GI bleeding, and there is a risk of recurrent bleeding, especially with continued immunosuppression.
5. **Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI):** The patient has multiple central lines, which increases the risk of CLABSI, which can lead to sepsis and increased mortality.
6. **Sepsis-related organ dysfunction:** The patient's sepsis is not fully controlled, and there is a risk of sepsis-related organ dysfunction, which can lead to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.
7. **GVHD:** The patient's GVHD is suspected, and there is a risk of GVHD progression, which can lead to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's oxygenation and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Maintain strict infection control measures to prevent VAP and CLABSI.
3. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis aggressively, including adjusting antibiotics and antivirals as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust medications accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's GI bleeding risk and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
6. Consider consulting with a specialist in infectious diseases and hematology to optimize the patient's treatment plan.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's GVHD risk and adjust immunosuppressive therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with ALL who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is currently admitted to the ICU with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. The patient's condition has improved slightly, with increased oxygenation while in the prone position and improved appearance of lungs on CXR.

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* Anemia: Hct stable, no recurrence of GI bleeding
* ARF: Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
* Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission, but improved significantly in the past few days
* Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear, but will continue to monitor given Voriconazole use
* ALL: On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation
* Hep B: Will re-start Lamivudine

The patient is currently on the following medications:

* Propofol for sedation
* Methadone for pain control
* Midazolam for sedation
* Cisatracurium for paralysis
* Voriconazole for antifungal prophylaxis
* Linezolid for VRE coverage
* Gancyclovir for CMV prophylaxis
* Bactrim for PNA prophylaxis
* Lasix for fluid management
* Solumedrol for immunosuppression
* Lamivudine for Hep B prophylaxis

The patient's vital signs are:

* Tmax: 36.5 C
* Tcurrent: 35.7 C
* HR: 60 bpm
* BP: 104/62 mmHg
* RR: 18 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 91%

The patient's physical examination is:

* Intubated, sedated, not responsive to voice
* Pupils are equal and minimally reactive to light, +scleral edema
* Right subjunctival hemorrhage
* ETT in place
* Ventilated breaths
* Clear breath sounds
* No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient's oxygenation has improved, but the patient is still on high FiO2 and may require further weaning.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis has improved, but the patient is still at risk for further infection.
* Volume overload: The patient has had significant volume overload since admission, but the patient's fluid management has improved.
* Elevated LFTs: The etiology of the patient's elevated LFTs is unclear, but the patient's liver function may continue to be monitored.
* ALL: The patient is on chronic immunosuppression and may be at risk for further complications.
* Hep B: The patient will be restarted on Lamivudine for Hep B prophylaxis.

Based on the patient's condition and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and adjust FiO2 as tolerated.
* Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids.
* Monitor the patient's volume status and adjust fluid management as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust medications as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's ALL and adjust immunosuppression as necessary.
* Restart Lamivudine for Hep B prophylaxis.
* Continue to provide supportive care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Currently
   off NO, remains on paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by
   measurements) and possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary
   edema.  Unclear as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and
   consider ECMO evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).
   [**Hospital3 **] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 38), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 resume TF, but limited by parlytics.  [**Month (only) 51**] need to
   initiate TPN.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplant over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient has a history of allergy to cefepime, and he has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and sedatives. His current medications include midazolam, cisatracurium, furosemide, and propofol.

The patient's physical examination reveals a normal temperature, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96%. His cardiac examination is normal, with a sinus bradycardia and a blood pressure of 119/71 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.5 K/uL, a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL, and a platelet count of 264 K/uL. His liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 51 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 41 IU/L. His electrolyte levels are normal, with a sodium level of 138 mmol/L, a potassium level of 4.2 mmol/L, and a chloride level of 103 mmol/L.

The patient's diagnosis is respiratory failure, ARDS, and possible infection. His treatment plan includes mechanical ventilation, inhaled nitric oxide (NO), and antibiotics. He is also receiving sedatives and analgesics to manage his pain and discomfort.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is still at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying disease and the use of mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunocompromised state and the use of invasive devices such as central lines and urinary catheters.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but he is at risk for cardiac complications such as cardiogenic pulmonary edema and arrhythmias due to his underlying disease and the use of sedatives and analgesics.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is stable, but he is at risk for neurological complications such as seizures and stroke due to his underlying disease and the use of sedatives and analgesics.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status is stable, but he is at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as nausea and vomiting due to his underlying disease and the use of sedatives and analgesics.
6. Hematological complications: The patient's hematological status is stable, but he is at risk for hematological complications such as bleeding and anemia due to his underlying disease and the use of anticoagulants.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Currently
   off NO, remains on paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by
   measurements) and possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary
   edema.  Unclear as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and
   consider ECMO evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).
   [**Hospital3 **] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 38), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.

 resume TF, but limited by parlytics.  [**Month (only) 51**] need to
   initiate TPN.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He has also developed pulmonary infiltrates, which are attributed to ARDS and possibly CMV infection. The patient has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and has shown some improvement in his respiratory status.

The patient has also developed several other complications, including:

* Hypoxemia, which is attributed to a right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo and may be eligible for longer-acting NO therapy.
* Lactic acidosis, which is persistent and may reflect evolving sepsis.
* Alkalemia, which is likely due to contraction alkalosis in the context of active diuresis.
* Acute renal failure, which has resolved and is being monitored.
* Elevated liver function tests (LFTs), which may be a component of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
* Fluid overload, which is being addressed through diuresis and fluid restriction.
* Sepsis, which has resolved and the patient is off pressors.

The patient's current medications include:

* Inhaled/exogenous NO
* Paralytics
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Steroids for empirical Pneumocystis treatment
* Lamivudine for hepatitis B
* Lasix drip for fluid management

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation with the goal of decreasing FiO2 to <60% if possible
* Adjusting inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation
* Monitoring pleural pressures and CXR
* Preparing for tracheostomy tube placement if the patient improves
* Considering ECMO evaluation if the patient develops profound hypoxemia
* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics and monitoring for signs of infection
* Monitoring LFTs and considering treatment for GVHD
* Resuming total parenteral nutrition (TPN) once the patient is able to tolerate it

Potential Medical Complications:

* Further deterioration of respiratory status
* Development of pulmonary hypertension and right-to-left shunt
* Progression of ARDS and pulmonary infiltrates
* Sepsis or infection
* Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
* Acute renal failure
* Lactic acidosis
* Alkalemia
* Fluid overload
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Hypoxemia
* Hypotension
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Pulmonary embolism
* Deep vein thrombosis
* Stress ulcer
* VAP
* Catheter-related bloodstream infections
* Pneumonia
* Meningitis
* Sepsis
* Organ failure
* Death

   Ms. [**Known lastname **] is a 52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation (>200 days) complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal
   bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents
   with pneumonia/sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

 attributed to ARDS +/- GVHD, was

   aware.

   go up to 100% FiO2 in interim.

   Sepsis initially due to multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Signficant
   radiographic improvement on CXR.  Wide differential given
   immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for

s or organisms. BAL: report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL,

   galactomannan negative x 2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  .Pt. started

   - monitor lactic acidosis (persistent mild elevation may be evolving
   sepsis from VAP, urine, liver infx)

 attributed to ARDS +/- GVHD, was

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone a single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to pneumonia, sepsis, and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's condition has been complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She has developed a large left pneumothorax, which was treated with a chest tube placement.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.3°C (97.3°F)
* Heart rate: 59 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 109/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* PaO2/FiO2 ratio: 89

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 90% and is being treated with nitric oxide. Her pleural pressure is being monitored, and she is being followed closely for any signs of worsening respiratory failure.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 301 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 85 mg/dL
* Glucose: 129 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 402 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's diagnosis is:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS +/- GVHD
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Streptococcal bacteremia
* VRE UTI
* Suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation on AC settings with a FiO2 of 90%
* Wean off nitric oxide slowly
* Monitor pleural pressures
* Follow CXR
* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Monitor SaO2 and pO2
* Continue sedation and pain control
* Consider weaning from paralysis
* Advance ETT 1 cm
* Follow up with BMT and ID recommendations

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Streptococcal bacteremia
* VRE UTI
* GVHD-induced hepatitis
* Lactic acidosis
* Renal failure
* Hepatitis B reactivation

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to adjust the plan of care and prevent potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 52-year-old female with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) who underwent single cord blood transplantation. She developed CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presented with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and prone positioning with nitric oxide (NO) to improve oxygenation.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS. Weaning of FiO2 may be challenging, and the patient may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient's sepsis is multifocal, with a wide differential diagnosis, including pneumonia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. Monitoring of blood cultures and serial imaging studies is essential to guide management.
3. **GVHD:** The patient's GVHD-induced hepatitis may progress, leading to liver dysfunction and potential liver failure.
4. **VRE UTI:** The patient's VRE UTI may not be fully treated, leading to persistent infection and potential sepsis.
5. **CMV Viremia:** The patient's CMV viremia may not be fully controlled, leading to potential complications such as CMV pneumonia or colitis.
6. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to potential complications such as cardiovascular instability.
7. **Acute Kidney Injury (ARF):** The patient's ARF may progress, leading to potential complications such as chronic kidney disease or dialysis dependence.
8. **Volume Overload:** The patient's volume overload may worsen, leading to potential complications such as pulmonary edema or cardiac failure.
9. **Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs):** The patient's elevated LFTs may be due to GVHD, medications, or infection, and may require further evaluation and management.

**Plan:**

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and prone positioning with NO to improve oxygenation.
2. Monitor blood cultures and serial imaging studies to guide management of sepsis.
3. Adjust antimicrobial therapy based on culture results and patient response.
4. Monitor liver function tests and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Continue immunosuppressive therapy to manage GVHD and prevent rejection.
6. Monitor renal function and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent ARF.
7. Monitor volume status and adjust fluid management accordingly.
8. Continue antiviral therapy for CMV viremia.
9. Consider referral to a liver transplant center if GVHD-induced hepatitis is severe.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to
   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and consider ECMO
   evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).  [**Hospital1 11267**] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PNEUMOTHORAX, LEFT -- tension, attributed to positive pressure
   ventilation/barrotrauma.  Improved with left chest tube.  Maintain
   chest tube while on positive pressure ventilation.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   GI BLEED -- coffee ground NGT aspirate.  [**Month (only) 51**] represent gastritis or
   PUD.  Monitor exam and serial Hct.  GI consultation if Hct declines.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 33), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).  Improving.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 Resolved.  Attributed to ATN.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   Approaching baseline weight.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 hold TF while evaluating for GI bleed.  [**Month (only) 51**] need
   to initiate TPN.  Will require additional central line.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
